title: 114_hr2332
content: The Act titled "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a Transformational Infrastructure Competitive Grant Program. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a transformational infrastructure competitive grant program under the Secretary of Transportation. Grants can be awarded to state governments, local governments, transit agencies, and port authorities for eligible projects like highway or bridge improvements. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a competitive grant program for infrastructure projects, including interstate rehabilitation, rural road improvements, bridge reconstruction, seismic retrofit projects, public transportation projects, rail transportation projects, and port infrastructure investments. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a competitive grant program for infrastructure projects, including interstate rehabilitation, rural road improvements, bridge reconstruction, seismic retrofit projects, public transportation projects, rail transportation projects, and port infrastructure investments. The Secretary shall coordinate grants for water infrastructure projects with the EPA and the Army. Eligible entities must submit applications for grants in the required format and timeframe. The Secretary will issue regulations for grant criteria within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Criteria will include financial commitments for proposed projects from non-Federal sources. The Federal share of project costs will be determined. The Federal share of project costs for grants under subsection (b) cannot exceed 100 percent. Grants must be distributed equitably, address urban and rural needs, promote veteran employment, and support small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. Each project funded under this Act must comply with Title 40 requirements and Buy America provisions, ensuring that all iron, steel, and manufactured goods used are produced in the United States, with exceptions granted by the Secretary if in the public interest or if not enough domestic production is available. The Secretary may waive Buy America provisions if domestic production is insufficient or if costs increase by more than 25%. Justifications for waivers must be published. The subsection must align with international agreements. Transparency and accountability are required in program implementation. The Secretary is required to ensure efficient use of grants, provide public information on grants, and report to Congress on grant progress. Additionally, coordination with other agencies is mandated for streamlined environmental reviews. Authorization of Appropriations: The Secretary is authorized to appropriate $985 billion for grants under the program from 2016 to 2020. 85% of the funds will be used for projects in subsection (c)(1)(A), (B), or (C), 2% for projects in subsection (c)(1)(D), and 4% for projects in subsection (c)(1)(E). Authorization of Appropriations: $985 billion authorized for grants from 2016 to 2020. Funds allocated as follows: 85% for projects in subsection (c)(1)(A), (B), or (C); 2% for projects in subsection (c)(1)(D); and 4% for projects in subsection (c)(1)(E) and (F). The Nation Building Here at Home Financing Initiative is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation, will establish a Nation Building Here at Home Financing Initiative within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Treasury Secretary may issue bonds up to $300 billion with specific characteristics, and the proceeds will be available to the Secretary of Transportation. The Secretary of Transportation may use proceeds from bonds issued under subsection (b) to carry out the program established under section 2(a) of this Act. SEC. 4. REPORT. The Secretary of Transportation must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment, detailing the transportation needs of the United States for the next 20, 30, and 50 years.
